questiontext.text:
HMS Belfast is a warship situated on the River Thames. Its guns are aimed to fire at a motorway service station a distance, $$D$$, 12 km away.


1. Assuming no air resistance, and that the ship and service station are at the same height above sea level, at what velocity must the shells leave the guns in order to reach the service station in a time, $$T$$, of 23 s?

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Velocity= {1:NUMERICAL:=533.8:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s


2. The maximum firing range of the HMS Belfast front guns at 45 degrees, taking air resistance into account, is stated to be 23.3 km.

The stated maximum velocity at which the shells leave the gun is 1514 m/s.

Each shell weighs 53 kg. Calculate the energy loss of the shells due to air resistance when they are fired to the maximum range at 45 degrees.

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=55:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #1).

generalfeedback.text:
Let initial velocity = $$V_o$$, and angle of trajectory = $$\phi$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$12000=V_o.cos(\phi).23$$


Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{12000 }{23 }=521.7m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =11.5$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times11.5)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times11.5=112.7$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{112.7 }{521.7 }=0.216=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=12.2^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=533.8$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times53\times (1514^2-478^2)=54688368$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=55$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image 1 adapted from 'http://www.frankharris.co.uk/latest-news/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/hms_belfast_04@gallerymain.jpg'

Image 2 adapted from 'http://www.alanpedia.com/physics_projectile_motion/projectile_motion_clip_image002.gif'

hint.text:
HINT

First of all, work out the velocity in the x-direction, and then obtain an expression for the initial velocity in the y-direction. Then combine these two expressions to calculate the angle of trajectory of the shells, and then their velocity.

For the second question, calculate the initial velocity to achieve the maximum given range with no air resistance, when fired at 45 degrees. Then calculate the difference in kinetic energy between the shells when fired at this speed compared to the speed given in the question.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{27000 }{36 }=750m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =18$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times18)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times18=176.4$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{176.4 }{750 }=0.235=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=13.2^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=770.5$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times66\times (1550^2-478^2)=71742528$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=72$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image 2 adapted from 'http://www.alanpedia.com/physics_projectile_motion/projectile_motion_clip_image002.gif'

For the second question, calculate the initial velocity to achieve the maximum given range with no air resistance, when fired at 45 degrees. Then calculate the difference in kinetic energy between the shells when fired at this speed compared to the speed given in the question.

questiontext.text:

Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times52\times (1534^2-478^2)=55241472$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=55$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For the second question, calculate the initial velocity to achieve the maximum given range with no air resistance, when fired at 45 degrees. Then calculate the difference in kinetic energy between the shells when fired at this speed compared to the speed given in the question.

questiontext.text:
HMS Belfast is a warship situated on the River Thames. Its guns are aimed to fire at a motorway service station a distance, $$D$$, 14 km away.


1. Assuming no air resistance, and that the ship and service station are at the same height above sea level, at what velocity must the shells leave the guns in order to reach the service station in a time, $$T$$, of 23 s?

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Velocity= {1:NUMERICAL:=619:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s


2. The maximum firing range of the HMS Belfast front guns at 45 degrees, taking air resistance into account, is stated to be 23.3 km.

The stated maximum velocity at which the shells leave the gun is 1511 m/s.

Each shell weighs 55 kg. Calculate the energy loss of the shells due to air resistance when they are fired to the maximum range at 45 degrees.

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=57:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #14).

generalfeedback.text:
Let initial velocity = $$V_o$$, and angle of trajectory = $$\phi$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$14000=V_o.cos(\phi).23$$


Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{14000 }{23 }=608.7m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =11.5$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times11.5)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times11.5=112.7$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{112.7 }{608.7 }=0.185=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=10.5^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=619$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times55\times (1511^2-478^2)=56502517.5$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=57$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image 2 adapted from 'http://www.alanpedia.com/physics_projectile_motion/projectile_motion_clip_image002.gif'

hint.text:
HINT

First of all, work out the velocity in the x-direction, and then obtain an expression for the initial velocity in the y-direction. Then combine these two expressions to calculate the angle of trajectory of the shells, and then their velocity.

For the second question, calculate the initial velocity to achieve the maximum given range with no air resistance, when fired at 45 degrees. Then calculate the difference in kinetic energy between the shells when fired at this speed compared to the speed given in the question.

questiontext.text:
HMS Belfast is a warship situated on the River Thames. Its guns are aimed to fire at a motorway service station a distance, $$D$$, 26 km away.


1. Assuming no air resistance, and that the ship and service station are at the same height above sea level, at what velocity must the shells leave the guns in order to reach the service station in a time, $$T$$, of 25 s?

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Velocity= {1:NUMERICAL:=1047.2:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s


2. The maximum firing range of the HMS Belfast front guns at 45 degrees, taking air resistance into account, is stated to be 23.3 km.

The stated maximum velocity at which the shells leave the gun is 1510 m/s.

Each shell weighs 51 kg. Calculate the energy loss of the shells due to air resistance when they are fired to the maximum range at 45 degrees.

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=52:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #20).

generalfeedback.text:
Let initial velocity = $$V_o$$, and angle of trajectory = $$\phi$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$26000=V_o.cos(\phi).25$$


Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{26000 }{25 }=1040m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =12.5$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times12.5)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times12.5=122.5$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{122.5 }{1040 }=0.118=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=6.7^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=1047.2$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times51\times (1510^2-478^2)=52316208$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=52$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Each shell weighs 56 kg. Calculate the energy loss of the shells due to air resistance when they are fired to the maximum range at 45 degrees.

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=58:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #26).

generalfeedback.text:
Let initial velocity = $$V_o$$, and angle of trajectory = $$\phi$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$22000=V_o.cos(\phi).33$$


Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{22000 }{33 }=666.7m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =16.5$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times16.5)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times16.5=161.7$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{161.7 }{666.7 }=0.243=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=13.6^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=686$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times56\times (1522^2-478^2)=58464000$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=58$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image 2 adapted from 'http://www.alanpedia.com/physics_projectile_motion/projectile_motion_clip_image002.gif'

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{112.7 }{739.1 }=0.152=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=8.7^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=747.7$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times66\times (1511^2-478^2)=67803021$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=68$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For the second question, calculate the initial velocity to achieve the maximum given range with no air resistance, when fired at 45 degrees. Then calculate the difference in kinetic energy between the shells when fired at this speed compared to the speed given in the question.

questiontext.text:
HMS Belfast is a warship situated on the River Thames. Its guns are aimed to fire at a motorway service station a distance, $$D$$, 16 km away.


1. Assuming no air resistance, and that the ship and service station are at the same height above sea level, at what velocity must the shells leave the guns in order to reach the service station in a time, $$T$$, of 37 s?

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Velocity= {1:NUMERICAL:=468.9:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s


2. The maximum firing range of the HMS Belfast front guns at 45 degrees, taking air resistance into account, is stated to be 23.3 km.

The stated maximum velocity at which the shells leave the gun is 1517 m/s.

Each shell weighs 64 kg. Calculate the energy loss of the shells due to air resistance when they are fired to the maximum range at 45 degrees.

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=66:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #33).

generalfeedback.text:
Let initial velocity = $$V_o$$, and angle of trajectory = $$\phi$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$16000=V_o.cos(\phi).37$$


Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{16000 }{37 }=432.4m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =18.5$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times18.5)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times18.5=181.3$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{181.3 }{432.4 }=0.419=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=22.7^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=468.9$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times64\times (1517^2-478^2)=66329760$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=66$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times53\times (1525^2-478^2)=55574236.5$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=56$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

hint.text:
HINT

First of all, work out the velocity in the x-direction, and then obtain an expression for the initial velocity in the y-direction. Then combine these two expressions to calculate the angle of trajectory of the shells, and then their velocity.

For the second question, calculate the initial velocity to achieve the maximum given range with no air resistance, when fired at 45 degrees. Then calculate the difference in kinetic energy between the shells when fired at this speed compared to the speed given in the question.

questiontext.text:
HMS Belfast is a warship situated on the River Thames. Its guns are aimed to fire at a motorway service station a distance, $$D$$, 11 km away.


1. Assuming no air resistance, and that the ship and service station are at the same height above sea level, at what velocity must the shells leave the guns in order to reach the service station in a time, $$T$$, of 29 s?

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Velocity= {1:NUMERICAL:=405.1:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s


2. The maximum firing range of the HMS Belfast front guns at 45 degrees, taking air resistance into account, is stated to be 23.3 km.

The stated maximum velocity at which the shells leave the gun is 1525 m/s.

Each shell weighs 67 kg. Calculate the energy loss of the shells due to air resistance when they are fired to the maximum range at 45 degrees.

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=70:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #39).

generalfeedback.text:
Let initial velocity = $$V_o$$, and angle of trajectory = $$\phi$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$11000=V_o.cos(\phi).29$$


Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{11000 }{29 }=379.3m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =14.5$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times14.5)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times14.5=142.1$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{142.1 }{379.3 }=0.375=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=20.5^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=405.1$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times67\times (1525^2-478^2)=70254223.5$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=70$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image 1 adapted from 'http://www.frankharris.co.uk/latest-news/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/hms_belfast_04@gallerymain.jpg'

Image 2 adapted from 'http://www.alanpedia.com/physics_projectile_motion/projectile_motion_clip_image002.gif'

questiontext.text:
HMS Belfast is a warship situated on the River Thames. Its guns are aimed to fire at a motorway service station a distance, $$D$$, 29 km away.


1. Assuming no air resistance, and that the ship and service station are at the same height above sea level, at what velocity must the shells leave the guns in order to reach the service station in a time, $$T$$, of 33 s?

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Velocity= {1:NUMERICAL:=893.5:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s


2. The maximum firing range of the HMS Belfast front guns at 45 degrees, taking air resistance into account, is stated to be 23.3 km.

The stated maximum velocity at which the shells leave the gun is 1518 m/s.

Each shell weighs 52 kg. Calculate the energy loss of the shells due to air resistance when they are fired to the maximum range at 45 degrees.

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=54:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #45).

generalfeedback.text:
Let initial velocity = $$V_o$$, and angle of trajectory = $$\phi$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$29000=V_o.cos(\phi).33$$


Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{29000 }{33 }=878.8m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =16.5$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times16.5)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times16.5=161.7$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{161.7 }{878.8 }=0.184=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=10.4^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=893.5$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times52\times (1518^2-478^2)=53971840$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=54$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image 1 adapted from 'http://www.frankharris.co.uk/latest-news/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/hms_belfast_04@gallerymain.jpg'

Image 2 adapted from 'http://www.alanpedia.com/physics_projectile_motion/projectile_motion_clip_image002.gif'

hint.text:
HINT

First of all, work out the velocity in the x-direction, and then obtain an expression for the initial velocity in the y-direction. Then combine these two expressions to calculate the angle of trajectory of the shells, and then their velocity.

For the second question, calculate the initial velocity to achieve the maximum given range with no air resistance, when fired at 45 degrees. Then calculate the difference in kinetic energy between the shells when fired at this speed compared to the speed given in the question.

$$\Delta KE=55$$ MJ

Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{17000 }{32 }=531.3m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =16$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times16)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times16=156.8$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{156.8 }{531.3 }=0.295=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=16.4^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=553.9$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times51\times (1522^2-478^2)=53244000$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=53$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image 2 adapted from 'http://www.alanpedia.com/physics_projectile_motion/projectile_motion_clip_image002.gif'

For the second question, calculate the initial velocity to achieve the maximum given range with no air resistance, when fired at 45 degrees. Then calculate the difference in kinetic energy between the shells when fired at this speed compared to the speed given in the question.

questiontext.text:
HMS Belfast is a warship situated on the River Thames. Its guns are aimed to fire at a motorway service station a distance, $$D$$, 20 km away.


1. Assuming no air resistance, and that the ship and service station are at the same height above sea level, at what velocity must the shells leave the guns in order to reach the service station in a time, $$T$$, of 37 s?

Velocity= {1:NUMERICAL:=570.1:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=74:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times69\times (1546^2-478^2)=74576304$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=75$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

questiontext.text:
HMS Belfast is a warship situated on the River Thames. Its guns are aimed to fire at a motorway service station a distance, $$D$$, 20 km away.


1. Assuming no air resistance, and that the ship and service station are at the same height above sea level, at what velocity must the shells leave the guns in order to reach the service station in a time, $$T$$, of 31 s?

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Velocity= {1:NUMERICAL:=662.8:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s


2. The maximum firing range of the HMS Belfast front guns at 45 degrees, taking air resistance into account, is stated to be 23.3 km.

The stated maximum velocity at which the shells leave the gun is 1547 m/s.

Each shell weighs 62 kg. Calculate the energy loss of the shells due to air resistance when they are fired to the maximum range at 45 degrees.

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=67:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #58).

generalfeedback.text:
Let initial velocity = $$V_o$$, and angle of trajectory = $$\phi$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$20000=V_o.cos(\phi).31$$


Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{20000 }{31 }=645.2m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =15.5$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times15.5)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times15.5=151.9$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{151.9 }{645.2 }=0.235=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=13.2^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=662.8$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times62\times (1547^2-478^2)=67106475$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=67$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image 2 adapted from 'http://www.alanpedia.com/physics_projectile_motion/projectile_motion_clip_image002.gif'

hint.text:
HINT

First of all, work out the velocity in the x-direction, and then obtain an expression for the initial velocity in the y-direction. Then combine these two expressions to calculate the angle of trajectory of the shells, and then their velocity.

For the second question, calculate the initial velocity to achieve the maximum given range with no air resistance, when fired at 45 degrees. Then calculate the difference in kinetic energy between the shells when fired at this speed compared to the speed given in the question.

questiontext.text:
HMS Belfast is a warship situated on the River Thames. Its guns are aimed to fire at a motorway service station a distance, $$D$$, 30 km away.


1. Assuming no air resistance, and that the ship and service station are at the same height above sea level, at what velocity must the shells leave the guns in order to reach the service station in a time, $$T$$, of 37 s?

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Velocity= {1:NUMERICAL:=830.8:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s


2. The maximum firing range of the HMS Belfast front guns at 45 degrees, taking air resistance into account, is stated to be 23.3 km.

The stated maximum velocity at which the shells leave the gun is 1542 m/s.

Each shell weighs 63 kg. Calculate the energy loss of the shells due to air resistance when they are fired to the maximum range at 45 degrees.

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=68:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #64).

generalfeedback.text:
Let initial velocity = $$V_o$$, and angle of trajectory = $$\phi$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$30000=V_o.cos(\phi).37$$


Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{30000 }{37 }=810.8m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =18.5$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times18.5)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times18.5=181.3$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{181.3 }{810.8 }=0.224=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=12.6^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=830.8$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times63\times (1542^2-478^2)=67702320$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=68$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=60:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #70).

generalfeedback.text:
Let initial velocity = $$V_o$$, and angle of trajectory = $$\phi$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$14000=V_o.cos(\phi).30$$


Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{14000 }{30 }=466.7m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =15$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times15)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times15=147$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{147 }{466.7 }=0.315=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=17.5^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=489.3$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times55\times (1548^2-478^2)=59615050$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=60$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image 2 adapted from 'http://www.alanpedia.com/physics_projectile_motion/projectile_motion_clip_image002.gif'

Therefore:

$$\phi=10.3^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=852.4$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times57\times (1546^2-478^2)=61606512$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=62$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

questiontext.text:
HMS Belfast is a warship situated on the River Thames. Its guns are aimed to fire at a motorway service station a distance, $$D$$, 17 km away.


1. Assuming no air resistance, and that the ship and service station are at the same height above sea level, at what velocity must the shells leave the guns in order to reach the service station in a time, $$T$$, of 32 s?

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Velocity= {1:NUMERICAL:=553.9:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s


2. The maximum firing range of the HMS Belfast front guns at 45 degrees, taking air resistance into account, is stated to be 23.3 km.

The stated maximum velocity at which the shells leave the gun is 1513 m/s.

Each shell weighs 57 kg. Calculate the energy loss of the shells due to air resistance when they are fired to the maximum range at 45 degrees.

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=59:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #77).

generalfeedback.text:
Let initial velocity = $$V_o$$, and angle of trajectory = $$\phi$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$17000=V_o.cos(\phi).32$$


Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{17000 }{32 }=531.3m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =16$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times16)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times16=156.8$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{156.8 }{531.3 }=0.295=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=16.4^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=553.9$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times57\times (1513^2-478^2)=58729522.5$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=59$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times69\times (1549^2-478^2)=74896636.5$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=75$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

hint.text:
HINT

First of all, work out the velocity in the x-direction, and then obtain an expression for the initial velocity in the y-direction. Then combine these two expressions to calculate the angle of trajectory of the shells, and then their velocity.

For the second question, calculate the initial velocity to achieve the maximum given range with no air resistance, when fired at 45 degrees. Then calculate the difference in kinetic energy between the shells when fired at this speed compared to the speed given in the question.

questiontext.text:
HMS Belfast is a warship situated on the River Thames. Its guns are aimed to fire at a motorway service station a distance, $$D$$, 17 km away.


1. Assuming no air resistance, and that the ship and service station are at the same height above sea level, at what velocity must the shells leave the guns in order to reach the service station in a time, $$T$$, of 27 s?

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Velocity= {1:NUMERICAL:=643.4:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s


2. The maximum firing range of the HMS Belfast front guns at 45 degrees, taking air resistance into account, is stated to be 23.3 km.

The stated maximum velocity at which the shells leave the gun is 1538 m/s.

Each shell weighs 65 kg. Calculate the energy loss of the shells due to air resistance when they are fired to the maximum range at 45 degrees.

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=69:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #83).

generalfeedback.text:
Let initial velocity = $$V_o$$, and angle of trajectory = $$\phi$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$17000=V_o.cos(\phi).27$$


Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{17000 }{27 }=629.6m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =13.5$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times13.5)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times13.5=132.3$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{132.3 }{629.6 }=0.21=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=11.9^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=643.4$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times65\times (1538^2-478^2)=69451200$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=69$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image 2 adapted from 'http://www.alanpedia.com/physics_projectile_motion/projectile_motion_clip_image002.gif'

1. Assuming no air resistance, and that the ship and service station are at the same height above sea level, at what velocity must the shells leave the guns in order to reach the service station in a time, $$T$$, of 26 s?

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Velocity= {1:NUMERICAL:=855.7:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s


2. The maximum firing range of the HMS Belfast front guns at 45 degrees, taking air resistance into account, is stated to be 23.3 km.

The stated maximum velocity at which the shells leave the gun is 1520 m/s.

Each shell weighs 68 kg. Calculate the energy loss of the shells due to air resistance when they are fired to the maximum range at 45 degrees.

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=71:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #89).

generalfeedback.text:
Let initial velocity = $$V_o$$, and angle of trajectory = $$\phi$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$22000=V_o.cos(\phi).26$$


Where $$s$$ is displacement $$D$$; $$u$$ is initial velocity; $$a$$ is acceleration (which is zero in the x-direction); and $$t$$ is time $$T$$.

Therefore $$V_o.cos(\phi)=\frac{22000 }{26 }=846.2m/s$$


Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =13$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times13)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times13=127.4$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{127.4 }{846.2 }=0.151=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=8.6^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=855.7$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times68\times (1520^2-478^2)=70785144$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=71$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image 1 adapted from 'http://www.frankharris.co.uk/latest-news/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/hms_belfast_04@gallerymain.jpg'

Image 2 adapted from 'http://www.alanpedia.com/physics_projectile_motion/projectile_motion_clip_image002.gif'

hint.text:

First of all, work out the velocity in the x-direction, and then obtain an expression for the initial velocity in the y-direction. Then combine these two expressions to calculate the angle of trajectory of the shells, and then their velocity.

For the second question, calculate the initial velocity to achieve the maximum given range with no air resistance, when fired at 45 degrees. Then calculate the difference in kinetic energy between the shells when fired at this speed compared to the speed given in the question.

Next, looking at the y-direction, the maximum height attained by the shells occurs at $$\frac{T }{2 } =20$$ s, at which point the shells' vertical velocity, $$v$$, is zero.


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ gives:

$$0=V_o.sin(\phi)+(-9.8\times20)$$

Therefore:

$$V_o.sin(\phi)=9.8\times20=196$$ m/s.


Using the identity $$tan\phi =\frac{sin\phi }{cos\phi }$$ gives:

$$\frac{V_o.sin(\phi) }{V_o.cos(\phi) }=\frac{196 }{575 }=0.341=tan(\phi)$$

Therefore:

$$\phi=18.8^o$$

Using

$$V_o=(\frac{T}{2}.9.8.sin(\phi))$$

OR

$$V_o={\frac{(1000.D)}{(T.cos(\phi))}$$

gives:

$$V_o=607.5$$ m/s.


To answer the second part of the question we need to find the value of $$V_o$$ that would produce a range of 23.3km with no air resistance:



Again applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ in the x-direction gives:

$$s=V_o.cos(45).t=23300$$

Therefore:

$$(1)$$ $$V_o.t=32951.2$$


Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

$$V_o.sin(45)=g.\frac{t}{2}$$

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$


$$\Delta KE=\frac{1}{2}\times59\times (1517^2-478^2)=61147747.5$$ J.


$$\Delta KE=61$$ MJ


(Remember to convert from km to m in all calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image 2 adapted from 'http://www.alanpedia.com/physics_projectile_motion/projectile_motion_clip_image002.gif'

For the second question, calculate the initial velocity to achieve the maximum given range with no air resistance, when fired at 45 degrees. Then calculate the difference in kinetic energy between the shells when fired at this speed compared to the speed given in the question.

questiontext.text:
HMS Belfast is a warship situated on the River Thames. Its guns are aimed to fire at a motorway service station a distance, $$D$$, 27 km away.


1. Assuming no air resistance, and that the ship and service station are at the same height above sea level, at what velocity must the shells leave the guns in order to reach the service station in a time, $$T$$, of 30 s?

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Velocity= {1:NUMERICAL:=911.9:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s


2. The maximum firing range of the HMS Belfast front guns at 45 degrees, taking air resistance into account, is stated to be 23.3 km.

The stated maximum velocity at which the shells leave the gun is 1541 m/s.

Each shell weighs 53 kg. Calculate the energy loss of the shells due to air resistance when they are fired to the maximum range at 45 degrees.

(Give your answer correct to 2.s.f.)

(Again use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)

Energy Loss= {1:NUMERICAL:=57:1#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} MJ

(Question ID #96).

gives:

Applying $$v=u+a.t$$ in the y-direction at the top of the arc gives:

Which can be simplified to:

$$(2)$$ $$\frac{V_o}{t}=6.93$$


By dividing equation $$(1)$$ by equation $$(2)$$, we can derive the following expression:

$$t^2=3362.19$$

Therefore:

$$t=69$$ s, and $$V_o=478$$ m/s.

The next step is to find the difference in kinetic energy between the real conditions and the perfect conditions:

$$\Delta KE=(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{actual}^2)-(\frac{1}{2}.m.V_{perfect}^2)$$
